REPORT ON MANITOULIN ISLAND AGENCY FOR THE MONTH NOVEMBER, 1944

Diphtheria has broken out on Whitefish River Reserve, but since the children were all inoculated by Dr. Young last year, it is not expected to reach epidemic proportions. One of the school teacher's children first developed the disease, and although they are not sick, Dr. Young has got a positive swab from the teacher and both her children.

The school will consequently be closed until the doctor gets a negative swab. He took swabs of all the other children yesterday.

C.R. Johnston,
Indian Agent.

Re: Mr. Peter Fenez, Teacher
Whitefish Bay Indian Day School.

A letter from the above noted has been received, and a copy is attached for your information. I would respectfully submit the following comments related to Mr. Fenez's letter.

For some time past, the teacher has intimated to me that he could get a higher salary at other Agency Day Schools; particularly in the Port Arthur Agency; and the matter was discussed by him with Mr. Greenway, the Catholic School Inspector.

This in itself seems very irregular to me. First, in that there seems to be different salaries offered to teachers in the different Agencies, and a higher salary in some instances to teachers having very much smaller attendance than at the Whitefish Bay School.

Secondly, I do not favour, as an Agent, having a School Inspector discussing the matter of wages or inducing a settled teacher such as Mr. Fenez, to make a change. Mr. Fenez has done a very good job at Whitefish Bay and I feel confident in verifying the statements in his letter. Our associations have been cordial and we have worked together in a cooperative sense, to the benefit of the pupils at the school.

Mr. Fenez took unto himself a wife last September, and no doubt feels that it is up to him to better himself, and I in no way would care to step in his way. However, if an increase in salary is in order under your present regulations, and money available, I would recommend this request be given your favourable consideration.

No one is irreplaceable, but after giving some considerable time to the welfare and betterment of the Whitefish Bay pupils, I feel that changing and replacing teachers of Mr. Fenez's calibre, is not conducive to the advancement of our Indian children; regardless whether there may be teachers having special certificates, or not, as teachers with first hand knowledge of Indians are not easy to get.

Please do not consider the foregoing critical to Department methods. I only wish to place before you, in a small measure, my ideas in regard to the welfare and betterment of our Indian Day School pupils and give some encouragement to the Day School teachers as a group.

Norman Baldwin,
Indian Agent.
June 29, 1946.

Mr. Norman Paterson, Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ontario.

Mr. Peter Fenez
Teacher - White Fish Bay Indian
Day School

During his recent visit to this office, we had an opportunity of discussing conditions at the above school with Mr. Tom Roy, the chief of this reserve. He expressed the opinion that the Indians are discontented with the services of the present teacher. The serious shortage of teachers was pointed out to Mr. Roy and the possibility that it would be very difficult to obtain a replacement for Mr. Fenez.

It would be very much appreciated if you would discuss this complaint with Mr. Roy and also with the Roman Catholic missionary on this reserve. The impression was obtained that the actual conditions of the complaint would be revealed to yourself who is better acquainted with local conditions than we are.

Bernard F. Neary
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Ottawa, June 1, 1947.

Dear Mr. Jones:

We have received your application for classification on Indian school teachers' salary schedule. You have claimed classification as a Grade 2 teacher with a salary of $1,650. If you read the regulations carefully, you will note that only certificated teachers can be classified as Grade 2 teachers. You will fall into the Grade J category as you hold only a teaching permit and not a certificate. Your teacher training apparently consists only of a two weeks' course in Winnipeg. Therefore, this will mean that your salary will remain unchanged from its present rate of $1,120 until you have increased your qualifications. I would recommend that you see your local Provincial Inspector of Schools with a view to doing this as soon as possible.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard F. Keary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Mr. Peter Jones,
Teacher,
Whitefish Bay Indian Day School,
Whitefish Bay, Ontario.

Whitefish Bay Indian Day School,

I wish to thank you for your letter of March 22 particularly the information about Mr. Douglas and Mr. Jones. I, too, hope Mr. Douglas drops in to see me during the Easter holidays and that we have an opportunity of discussing our future plans (which I hope will be mutual).

I was pleased to find out that Mr. Jones intends to go to normal school and note that he will require at least five Grade Thirteen papers before he can do so. The information which you gave him was entirely correct and we would be quite willing to grant him a year's leave of absence without pay to attend Normal when he is ready. We certainly would try to give Mrs. Jones a small school so that she could help by earning money while he is at Normal School. At the present time Mr. Jones is a temporary civil servant and cannot apply for permanency until he gets a proper teaching certificate. Therefore, teaching at Kenora would not greatly affect his civil service standing because he is not yet permanent. As you suggest, I am writing to him directly and so far as he knows, am indicating that you have advised only as marked by pencil in your paragraph. I attach a copy of my letter to him for your information. I will write to him again when I hear further as to his plans. In the meantime please accept my sincere thanks for the interest which you have shown in our work in the past and are continuing to show at present. I hope to see you in Toronto for the Ontario Education Association Convention and will then be able to discuss these and other matters.

Sincerely yours,

Bernard F. Murray,
Superintendent of Education.

Dear Father Levigne:

I have for answer your letter of July 25, and I am pleased with the results of your advertising for teachers in the Enigma. You will probably note that I have written to several of our missionaries in the South and Alberta. Further, I have written to the Saskatchewan teachers who answered your advertisement in an attempt to interest them in positions in that province and possibly in Alberta.

Main River School

Mr. Ross has been transferred to the Main River school. It is too bad for the Main River Indians to lose such a very good teacher. However, he is just the type we need at Gauthier, and he is not lost to us.

You are probably aware of the isolated situation of the school at Main River, and I hope Mr. Ross will be able to improve conditions there. I am enclosing some photographs of the school and the Indians so that you may see what he will be able to do when he arrives. If he does not come, we will try to find another person at once. Would you please return the photographs after showing them to him?

I attach one of our application forms which he should complete and return to me. I assure him that he does not need teaching certificate nor experience. His salary will be $180 per year, therefore, he only as a Grade I teacher at the rate of $16.50 a teaching month.

Whitefish Bay Indian Day School

Further to my letter of October 31, I have today had an interview with a teacher who might be interested in this second room. She is an Indian girl from St. Regis and has had nine years of teaching experience. Her record is as follows:

1939-1941 - St. Regis Village
1941-1945 - Chenail
1946-1948 - Chetlain
1948-1949 - Caughnawaga R.C.

She has the equivalent of a Second Class Teaching Certificate. She is 32 years of age and had her teacher's training at the Institute of Pedagogy in Montreal. She is not an outstanding teacher but is steady and good with the primary grades.

When we hired three male teachers at Caughnawaga this year to replace the women lay teachers formerly there, she was not willing to accept a transfer to a school too far from her home because of the fact her mother was ill.

Now I understand she is prepared to accept a school in Ontario and I have given her your address. You can expect a letter from her with questions concerning the accessibility of the Whitefish Bay School.

Dear Miss Terrance,

Re: Whitefish Bay Indian Day School

Receipt is acknowledged of your letter dated the 10th of November, inquiring as to the location etc., of the a/n Day School.

This school is situated on the Whitefish Bay I.R. 32A, approximately 50 miles South East of Kenora.

It is accessible by Highway, Lake and Air. The Fort Frances Highway runs about ½ mile South of Sarrome Landing, which is situated on a Bay lying south of the Reserve, and is roughly 1 mile by Lake from the Day School. In the summer months, access to Reserve is made by outboards or canoes. During the freeze up walking from the highway or transportation by pony is the only means of travel. A daily bus service from Kenora serves the District.

There is a population of 185 on this Reserve composed of 86 men, 40 women and 57 boys and 52 girls under the age of 21. An average of 50 pupils are in attendance at this school. They are predominantly of the Catholic Faith with some few Protestants and pagans.

There is no R.C. Church on the Reserve. The Rev. Father Antonio Lascelle, O.M.I. is the missionary for this district and holds services in the school house periodically. There is a small R.C. Mission situated on the Fort Frances Highway near Sioux Narrows, this being about 10 miles from the Reserve.

The Band members on this Reserve make their living by Commercial Fishing, guiding and trapping. At Sioux Narrows there is a Post Office, Day School and 3 or 4 stores. This is a busy community during the summer months serving and catering to the Tourist Trade.

The present teacher, Mr. Peter Perez is married and have a little girl 2 years old. They are of French Canadian stock from Manitoba. Mr. and Mrs. Perez are a very nice couple and have taken a great interest in the welfare of this Band; and have made many friends in and around Sioux Narrows.
The new School as perhaps you are aware is a two room school with teacherage attached. It has a full basement, no running water or electric lights. Outside toilets for pupils and an inside toilet in the teacherage. It is situated about 300 yards from the lake and in the center of the Hamlet.

The Indians in this Agency are of the Ojibway tribe and with the exception of some aged Band members all speak fairly good English.

For your further information I am enclosing a map of the area.

I trust this information will be helpful to you in gaining a full picture of the location etc.

Yours very truly,

Norman Paterson,
Superintendent,
Kenora Indian Agency.

Dear Sir,

Me again! I have been thinking about the Whitefish Bay School, and it seems that the more I think about it the farther away it gets.

Is it not in any way possible to place me in a non-Catholic school closer to home until there is a vacancy in a Catholic one? I don't necessarily mean Caughnawaga, but anywhere close by.

If all the reports made against me at Cheltenham School have anything to do with all this stalling around, please would you give me a chance to tell my side of the story. I'm not trying to deny nor apologize for anything because my conscience is clear as far as that is concerned.

I was told of illness at the Cheltenham school. If it is serious enough to require a new teacher, do you suppose maybe Miss Beck and myself could be shifted around?
Maybe not yet, but I have great hopes for vacancy somewhere close by before Christmas. Till then, I'll just cross my fingers.

Yours truly,
Mary F. Terrance
November 18, 1949.

Whitefish Bay Indian Day School

Dear Mrs. Dashney:

You will recall that I wrote to you recently concerning a vacancy near Cornwall, Ontario. I have received a letter from a teacher indicating that she is not prepared to go to a new two-room school which we are building near Kenora. This teacher's mother has been ill and she does not wish to go too far from her home in Hogansburg.

The school is Whitefish Bay Day School and it is situated on the Whitefish Bay Indian Reserve approximately fifty miles south-east of Kenora. I can best describe the school by quoting from a recent letter from Mr. Norman Paterson, our Indian Superintendent, to the teacher formerly interested in this position.

"It is accessible by Highway, Lake and Air. The Fort Frances Highway runs about ½ mile South of Sammons Landing, which is situated on a Bay lying south of the Reserve, and is roughly 1 mile by Lake from the Day School. Mission situated on the Fort Frances Highway near Sioux Narrows, this being about 10 miles from the Reserve.

The present teacher, Mr. Peter Fenez is married and have a little girl 2 years old. They are of French Canadian stock from Manitoba. Mr. and Mrs. Fenez are a very nice couple and have taken a great interest in the welfare of this Band; and have made many friends in and around Sioux Narrows. Re: School teacher for Whitefish Bay, Kenora Agency.

Please find enclosed one Copy of letter received by Fr. Scheffer from M. Leo LISOWSKI seeking information regarding opening for teacher in an Indian School. Poveshell Indian Day School.

Dear Sir:

Father Schaffer referred to me your letter concerning the teaching position open on the Fort Alexander Reserve. Unfortunately, this has already been filled with a teacher who has a First Class Certificate and 15 years of experience.

However, there is a vacancy in Saskatchewan which might interest you. This is at a new school being erected on the Poveshell Indian Reserve in the Battleford Indian Agency.

I attach one of our standard application forms which I would like to have you complete and return to me so that we can review your qualifications and determine the salary which we can offer you. For further details on the Poveshell School, would you please write to Mr. J.P.B. Ostrander, Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies, 304 Post Office Building, Regina, Sask.

Sincerely yours,

Bernard F. Every,
Superintendent of Education.

Enc.
23 December, 1949.

Reverend Father A. Laselle, O.M.I.,
Box 40, Kenora, Ontario.

WHITEFISH BAY INDIAN DAY SCHOOL.

Dear Father Laselle:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of December 19. I have already been in correspondence with three teachers concerning the Whitefish Bay Day School. Mr. Lisowski wrote in concerning the Fort Alexander Day School. We have already accepted another teacher for this position, with a First Class Certificate and 15 years of experience. I believe we can place Mr. Lisowski in a day school in Saskatchewan, his home province. The teachers' quarters provide living accommodation for two single teachers and if one of the teachers is married, then alterations can be made in the basement to permit bedrooms being provided there. We do not wish to rent extra accommodation as these renting of teachers' quarters costs the Department a great deal of money and we are discouraging it everywhere.

I note that Mr. Jones might not be staying there after the end of the year term. I am also advised that the contractor will probably not finish this project until March 15, 1950. I believe that we can obtain the services of a single male teacher at that time and possibly replace Mr. Jones with a married couple for September, 1950.

In conclusion, may I extend to you my sincere Greetings.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard F. Murray,
Superintendent of Education

Citeau, August 20, 1925.

Sir,

I have your letter of the 13th instant, with general reference to the Whitefish Bay Indian Day School. The Department approves of the appointment of Mr. Ducharme at a salary of $70 per teaching month, and you may employ him immediately to supervise the completion of the building that will be used as classroom and teacher's residence. The Department will allow wood for the heating of both the classroom and the residence, but I regret that no transportation can be allowed the teacher and his family.

When the teacher arrives at the school, he should make requisition for whatever is required to complete the equipment and to conduct classes. Immediate and favourable consideration will be given to whatever you recommend. It should be remembered, however, that only what is absolutely necessary will be allowed, because of the experimental nature of this activity.

At the end of September you should in a separate communication make application for Mr. Ducharme's salary. His appointment as teacher will date from the day that he arrives at the school.

Yours obediently,

T. K. L. MacLennan,
For Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Frank Edwards, Esq.,

WORKING WITH WOOD

Nothing in the world gives so much real pleasure as making things.

—John Drinkwater

This is especially true of boys and girls — they just can't help making things. The satisfaction of actually doing something so that the outcome will be satisfying seems to be an inherent urge. It is easy to make things that are useful, things that are beautiful, things that are practical. This book contains patterns for making things out of wood, metal, glass, and other materials. It also contains instructions for making things out of paper, cardboard, and other materials. The book is divided into sections for different types of projects, such as furniture, toys, and crafts. Each section contains step-by-step instructions for making the projects, as well as suggestions for variations and modifications.

Elementary Handicraft

Contains patterns for toys, match boxes, clocks, bird feeders, and other items. The book also contains instructions for making these items. The patterns are easy to follow and the instructions are clear.

Things to Make With a Coping Saw

Contains patterns for window panes, bookends, desk sets, whale holders, toys, and other items. The patterns are easy to follow and the instructions are clear.

Crafts for Children

By Kathleen Buckle

Crafts for Children contains instructions for making various crafts out of wood, metal, glass, and other materials. The book also contains patterns for making these crafts. The patterns are easy to follow and the instructions are clear.

Teacher's Record Book

This is an inexpensive device where the teacher can conveniently record each child's progress from day to day. The book contains a list of subjects covered in each lesson, as well as space for recording the child's progress. The book is divided into sections for different grades, and each section contains a list of subjects covered in each lesson.

Arithmetic Bingo

Once or twice in a lifetime, something really new comes into the educational field. Arithmetic is learning to count.

It is the old game of Bingo adapted to Arithmetic. One set contains cards printed on the 100 Addition Facts, one on the 100 Subtraction Facts, one on the 100 Multiplication Facts, and one on the 70 Division Facts.

Full instructions for the various uses of the cards are given in the booklet enclosed. This booklet should be in your set.

This game has been tried out by a number of teachers who have enthusiastically acclaimed it as a good aid. They say, "The children thoroughly enjoy the game while learning their facts. It is a very effective means of enabling children to learn their facts."

On my requisition of September 10th (attached), I'm requesting a typewriter and a hectograph machine.

Both these items are greatly needed here as all reports for dispensing medicines and requisitions for school material and supplies have to be completed in quadruplicate.

Furthermore with the number of pupils in the school and the lack of books and material for seatwork etc., it will save hours of home labour and school blackboard work.

Hoping that you will co-operate with me in this request, I remain,

Yours truly,

(sgd) Peter Fences,

August 11th, 1949.

Dear Sir:

This will acknowledge receipt of your letter dated August 8, regarding the set of the Books of Knowledge for the Whitefish Bay Indian Day School.

My enrolment for Grade six and upwards for the coming term will be as follows, if the Department ever decides to erect building the new school you promised us three years ago.

There will be 55 pupils attending this day school in a few weeks time. You can imagine what it will be to have this number in a room 23 x 27, especially during the hot days and in winter time when everything is closed in.

I have to consider my health and the one of my pupils attending this school, and believe me Mr. Neary you would have to see the school the way it is now.

We have children from this reserve attending the Kenora R.C. school at St-Mary's, and if we had our new school they would be attending here on this reserve.

Therefore the enrolment for this coming term should be as follows;

Grade 6 - 4 pupils
Grade 7 - 5 " maybe six (one from St-Mary's)
Grade 8 - 3 " plus two girls who are coming back to school and 2 more from the Kenora R.C. School.

thus my enrolment should at least be even more than sixteen.

I will leave the matter with you Mr. Neary and you can decide what is best.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Sir,

Although it is not the custom for a teacher of an Indian Day School to write directly to The Department officially, I think that after reading this letter, you will give me your approval.

By this time, any quantity returned for the quarter ending June the 30th must have reached you if it has not been delayed in Kenora by The Indian Agent.

You must have noticed that this school has been closed for two different periods during the last term.

First in the month of May which was reported to the Agent in due time.

The second period which is
the last week of June needs some personal explanations which if I don't give them myself will never reach you.

In 1932 the Town of Kenora was celebrating the 2nd centenary of the coming of the first white man to its shores. The celebration was going to take place on the 1st & 2nd of July. In the months of May and June of the same year the Indian Agent at treaty asked the Indians to come to town and organize a big "Pow-Wow" which they did and which was a real success. But since then, last year and this year and most probably for the years to come, unless some drastic measures are taken to stop it, when the middle of June comes, the Indians of this reserve as well as those of the other reserves start to go to town one by one taking their children with them, hoping
to renew the show they have put up in 1932. This year and the last I have told the parents of my pupils to wait until the school year be finished to go to town, but the temptation was too great. The result was that on the 23rd of June I was left there with a possible attendance of 5 pupils which had not showed up for school on the 21st of 22nd which were nice weather days. In front of these facts I decided to close school for the summer holidays.

Another thing I want to bring to your attention is the need of standard desks for this school. Last fall when we built the school we put up the building in quite a hurry. When it came to school furnishing as to desks, tables & chairs for the pupils, we took whatever lumber was left and made some. But the whole work is so poor that
I am not getting the full interest of the pupils in their schoolwork due to lack of equipment. I would ask you, if it is possible, to supply it with standard single desks and I believe until I get them it will be hard to make a success of this school.

Another thing I want to bring to your attention is the furnitures for the dwelling. When I came here four years ago I understood that the Department was supplying the furnitures for the dwelling. And last fall beside the $5.00 or so that was set aside for buying the material for putting the building up, I understand that $200.00 was sent to the Agent to supply the dwelling with furnitures.

August, 17th, 1934.

Dear Sir:

Referring to our letter 129-8-5 of July, 11th last, re "Whitefish Bay Day School."

We have repeatedly written to the Teacher to call at the Office when he is in Kenora, as he comes in frequently, but he has failed to do so.

At Annuity Payments he promised to give us a list of his requirements, and we now inclose a letter we have received from him.

We bought standard sized blinds for the windows and as they were a little too wide, we asked him to bring them in and we would have them cut to the proper size by the merchant from whom they were purchased, and you will notice in his letter he refuses to do this, and as we cannot get the size he wants from him, we are unable to do anything.

We also asked him what articles he had written to Ottawa about and he refuses this information, saying it is a personal matter between himself and the Department.

"We cannot understand his attitude in these matters, as we have done all in our power to make him comfortable at the school. We allowed his wife to use part of the building as a Post Office, at the request of the Keewatin Lumber Co. and other residents at Whitefish, so they could have a little more money, we have guaranteed his grocery bill on several occasions, and he also received advances on salary from the Department, so we think he has no cause for complaint.

We believe one of the reasons why the school has not been opened regularly, is that he has been transporting men in his boat to and from Kenora, for the Keewatin Lumber Co.

Regarding his requirements for the coming year, he says he does not want to rush a list, as he wants to have it complete."
He also wants the walls plastered before freeze up. We advised him in the first place not to plaster the walls last fall, but to chink them with Moss, till the logs dried out, but he insisted on the plastering, with the result that the plastering has fallen out, now that the logs have dried.

We consider he should be supplied with the single desks he requests, and these will be included in the estimates and if we can see the Teacher before the estimates go in, we will include whatever requirements we consider necessary.

He requests a balance of furniture for which $200.00 was granted, but this was expended as per E.R.1012 and 1080 Vote 188 1933-34.

We would suggest you communicate with the Separate School Inspector, Mr. Greening, who will be able to give you a report on the Teacher, and also as to our attitude and treatment of him, since he was appointed.

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 5th instant, with reference to the erection of a fence at the Whitefish Bay Indian Day School.

Expenditures in connection with Indian schools are not made from band funds. All the costs of Indian education are paid from parliamentary appropriation and, under these circumstances, the Department is not prepared to approve the resolution to expend $80.00 from the funds of the Whitefish Bay Band.

At the present time, the appropriation for Indian education has been completely assigned and, therefore, the Department is not prepared to authorize the expenditure that would be required for the fence at this school.

April 5, 1935.

The Department of Indian Affairs,
Toronto, Ontario.

Gentlemen:

A few months ago, the Chief and Councillor of the Whitefish Bay Indian Band submitted to the Department a demand for a band fund appropriation of $80.00 for the construction of a fence around the school property. This request, we have been told, has not been granted.

The purpose of the fence was partly in the cause of neatness but principally for the protection of a proposed garden. Under the circumstances, what with stray cattle and innumerable dogs all of which are always famished, a garden without a fence is out of the question. For the sake of the garden, then, and neatness of the premises, can't you reconsider this $90.00 appropriation from the funds of the Whitefish Bay Band?

Last year, a temporary dock was built at the foot of the school. It is now in such dangerous shape that I consider it unsafe for the use of the children. Cannot something be done toward constructing a new dock? I am certain that should the Department furnish spikes and a little food for the Indians, the latter would erect a safe and solid dock.

Another item requiring early attention is the school chimneys. If brick chimneys are not installed soon, there is a possibility of losing this creditable building. Why, for the sake of a few dollars, run such risks to life and property?

Very sincerely yours,
Dear Sir:

Inclosed please find a letter we have received from the Teacher at Whitefish Bay Day School. What he has asked for has been recommended by the Separate School Inspector Mr. Greening. It looks quite a lot but everything was burned of course when the school burned down, so we will be glad if you can possibly approve of the requisition.

Our estimates sent in last October included $80.00 for a brick chimney $75.00 for a ceiling in the residence and $75.00 for a shed.

The teacher also asks for some strong wire netting to protect the windows when the pupils are playing baseball.

This can be purchased locally at no great cost.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Indian Agent,

Assistant Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.
Ottawa, April 17th, 1935.

Sir,

With reference to your 108-21 of the 9th instant, I beg to say that you may arrange for the repairs to the chimneys at the Whitefish Bay Indian Day School at a cost of $80.00 and, also, the repairs to the ceiling in the teacher's residence at a cost of $75.00. Purchases should be made from firms on the approved list.

From the information contained in your letter, the Department does not see the necessity for the shed mentioned. Our funds are limited and, unless this is absolutely necessary, favourable consideration cannot be given to this expenditure.

In his letter, the teacher also requests the erection of a fence and repairs to the dock. Funds for these purposes are not available in the appropriation for Indian education.

You may purchase the wire netting required to cover the windows.

In a requisition recently received, the teacher requests ten desks; five fronts and five rears. Would it not be possible to do without these new desks for another year?

Dear Sir:

On my inspection of Whitefish Bay D. School on Wednesday 16th inst., I found the new school teacher Mr. Laflèche doing good work and popular with the priest, local white men and Indians.

We shall be glad if you will give us authority to purchase the necessary supplies of Cocoa, Sugar, Dry Milk and Oat Meal for the mid-day meal and presume you will be sending a further supply of making biscuits.

The teacher also requires Insulite to cover the ceiling of the class room 24' X 24', 12 pieces 2" X 4" X 16 feet for cross ties for ceiling of class room.

Laser and setting for porch 22 ft. X 10 ft.

Partition residence of either Insulite or V-joint on two doors.

To allow light to enter louver for window frames, curtains, etc., etc., etc.

Two Axes, One pointed shovel, One pointed rake, One pointed snout, One pointed hoe, Four eye bolts and rings, timbers to fit the frame.

Two Fire Pails, Two Fire Extinguishers, One Hose, One 6" Stove pipe ring, One 6" T. pipe and Six 6" T. pipe.

Most of these articles are asked for in our estimates, and would not cost more than $200.00 less food stuff.

If we had this material now Mr. Laflèche would do most of the work during the winter which would considerably save to the Department in labour.

Assistant Deputy Minister,

Dear Sir:

Last winter I received some Billy-
material which I used to make a ceiling
in the school room, partitions, cupboards,
wardrobe etc., in the residence. Right now
I am busy making an ice box. All this had
to be done as the place was offering very
little comfort to a man who has to do
his own housekeeping. It already looks
very different from what it was 8 mo.
ago when I first took charge of the
school.

The building is only a little over 2 yrs
old, but as the Indians had to put it up
in a hurry (in Nov.), green logs were being
used. After two yrs, these logs have shrunk
quite a bit, thus causing the plaster
to fall off. It makes the house very cold in the winter & causes the floors to look very gray, not to say dirty, hard to keep clean. The local agent, Capt. Edwards has already sent me some "lime," I shall need little more in addition to this, a small amount of cement and "lime" to prevent the plaster from cracking. So, I have sent a new list of requisitions—mostly all building material & hope to get it as soon as the boats begin to run.

The floors too, need to be painted, as the paint has all disappeared.

I have asked Capt. Edwards for some wallpaper, Board, Board or Plaster (something anyway) to finish the residence so soon as the plaster has been removed. Hope when this requisition is sent in it will be granted. It is badly needed.

May I be permitted to say that our local agent Capt. Edwards has always shown a very pronounced interest towards our local affairs & my personal activities. He has encouraged me a great deal.
I have gradually developed a great liking for the place & the work I have started. I wish to assure the Department that all my efforts will be directed towards the betterment of the place & the people placed so confidently in my charge. I thank you for everything you have done for me.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

Teacher.

Whitefish Bay Indian Day School

Further to our letter of April 9th, please be advised that the misunderstanding with regard to this school was caused by the fact that the councillors and yourself requested a two room school rather than the one room school originally requested by Chief Hoy.

Would you please assure the council that we do intend to build a school at Whitefish Bay, either this year or next year.

There are three possibilities raised after considering your letter of April 2nd,-

(a) That we erect a pre-fabricated teachers residence this year and the school next year. As you are probably aware, we are having a great deal of difficulty in getting contractors to erect schools which are located considerable distances from towns. We have already purchased four small teachers residences from a pre-fabricated construction firm and may consider doing the same at Whitefish Bay,

(b) That we construct a one room day school and residence combined,

(c) That we construct a two room day school and residence combined.
Major C.A.F. Clark, our educational Survey Officer is at present in the Yukon but is expected to be flying out shortly. Upon his return, it is our intention to send him to Kenora to further discuss with you the action which we should take with regard to this school.

Bernard F. Neary
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Sir,

I was at the school lately, and would suggest you authorize the same amount be expended for pupils lunches during the winter as was supplied last winter.

Dear Sir;

Mr Leon Trottier, Teacher at the Whitefish Bay Indian Bay School, informs me the foundations of the building are rotting away and should be repaired or replaced. He informs me he can get the Indians to get the logs and do the work for about $20.00 in the spring.

We could borrow a jack from the Lumber Company at the reserve, if authorized.

The teacher also requests us to supply him with the following articles:

- 6 jack knives,
- 6 coping saw frames,
- 1 box coping saw blades,
- 1 brace,
- 6 bits, ¼", ½", ¾", 3/8", 5/8", and 1",
- 1 level,
- 1 draw knife.

The above articles would not cost very much and are required for teaching the children carpentry, and handiwork, and would be a good investment, as the teacher has done a lot of carpenter work before teaching school.

I shall be glad to receive official authority.

Yours very truly,

Frank Edwards

Dear Sir;

I shall be glad to have authority to purchase materials for lunches for the pupils of the Whitefish Bay Indian Day School during the winter months.

We estimated for the following:

- 150 lbs Rolled Oats.
- 25 lb Bulk cocoa.
- 350 lbs granulated sugar.
- 35 lbs dry milk.
- 200 lbs Biscuits (Makino)

No biscuits were supplied last winter, and the teacher would like particularly to get some this winter.

There are 22 pupils attending this school.

An early reply will be appreciated, as the luncheons usually start at the beginning of October, and we usually purchase the articles from the Western Grocers (wholesale) Kenora, Ontario.

Very truly,

Dear Sir:

Upon receipt of Departmental letter, file 129-8-5, dated Ottawa, November 6, 1942, authorizing local purchase of midday meal supplies for the Whitefish Bay Indian Day School application was made to the local Wartime Prices and Trade Board Office for a permit to cover the purchase of the sugar included on this requisition. The local Wartime Prices representative, however, has no instructions in this respect.

If the foregoing information is correct will you kindly issue full instructions regarding the above and mail me a supply of the necessary forms - in order that the supplies for the Whitefish Bay School may be purchased at an early date.

Teacher - Peter Fenez -

The school is an old log building -- opened with full number of pupils in attendance - 28. Oil-cloth or linoleum required for living quarters. The toilets are in a disgraceful condition. Sept. 27th 1944.

Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa.

Re: 129-8-5., Whitefish Bay Indian Day School requirements.

In connection with your letter of the 19th instant I have checked into the matter with the teacher while at Whitefish yesterday.

He ordered a Congoleum rug 18 x 24 which was wrong. He required linoleum to cover two rooms as follows:
Bedroom - size, 9 feet 10½ inches by 9 feet 3 inches.
Sitting and dining room - 17 feet 3 inches by 13 feet.
The old floor covering has been removed as it was worn out.

Regarding the request for dishes, this is, I believe a necessity at this particular school. Mr. Fenez has at times our Treaty Party and other Department Officials. Last Spring there were seven in the party and we were invited to use his kitchen and dining room as it was very wet. A set of white porcelain dishes such as six cups and six saucers, plates and bowls would cost at Fife's Hardware approximately $8.00, and I would recommend they be purchased for the school.

There has never been a desk or chair at this school - a flat top ordinary table is now in use.

The foregoing is respectfully submitted for your information.

NP/C

Indian Agent.

Re- Requisition for School Supplies.

Attached hereto is a requisition for School Supplies received from Mr. Peter Fenez, teacher of the Whitefish Bay Indian Day School.

Mr. Fenez intends staying on the Reserve during the holidays, and has asked that he be paid for the general repairs and painting of the school, which he would undertake, along with the help of several members of the Band.

The school is in need of a general clean up and I would therefore recommend that Mr. Fenez be paid for six days labor at $4.00 per day - $24.00. This would in some measure, compensate him for the many hours he puts in at the school, for which, no remuneration is received.

Norman Paterson
Indian Agent.

Mr. Norman Paterson, Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.

I have your letter of the 16th instant, with reference to the request from the teacher, for supplies for midday meals for pupils of the Whitefish Bay Indian Day School.

While the Department is prepared to allow the same amount for midday meal purposes as last year, we do not intend to increase the amount. Due to payment of family allowances, it is reasonable to presume that the children will receive better food and should also be provided with more food for their midday lunch.

With regard to the items requested on the attached requisition, please let me know for what period of time these would be sufficient. You should also state why the teacher is asking for six sacks of rolled oats. It is difficult for me to understand exactly what purpose they could be used for in a lunch served at midday.

Philip Phelan,

Date: October 10th 1945
Schools:

Whitefish Bay Indian Day School:
Inspected repairs being done to this school July 5th, when visiting Whitefish Bay Indian Reserve. On August 16th inspected the Boys' Club Garden and the work done on the school house. School has been re-painted and whitewashed outside, window and door frames repaired and painted, new storm windows purchased and ready to put on. Teacher's living quarters has also been re-decorated and painted and school room painted & improved.

The Boys' Club garden of approximately an acre was in fair shape and some garden exhibits were sent in to Kenora Agricultural Fair, also some school exhibits such as embroidery and fret work, writing etc. Pupils received several prizes and it is hoped that the Boy's Club efforts will in some small measure encourage them to a continuance of this training.

Out of 400 live day old chickens received in June, some 200 or more had been lost through overcrowding. The balance has been distributed to 3 families and 100 kept by Mr. Peter Fenex, teacher, for the boys club. This school has had an increase in attendance and is now up to capacity.

Norman Paterson,
Indian Agent.

Dear Mr. Paterson:

In response to your letter of October 23rd, regarding the supplies for midday meals, I wish to state that midday meals have been served to the pupils of this day school since a number of weeks from October 1st, and that a request has been forwarded every year for the supply of rolled oats, sugar, cocoa, and milk.

Since the number of pupils is increasing and that a number of small children are too far from home to go for dinner, rolled oats and cocoa are served to them. Approximately 20 pupils are here for lunch and when the weather is cold or stormy everyone stays at the school.

Some children bring a few sandwiches.
from home and we serve them with a bowl
for two of porridge and a cup of cocoa, according
with all child's appetite.

Let me state that there is no waste in it
as the teacher serves the children herself and let
it take plenty of milk and sugar, just for one meal,
and also plenty of work besides the rest.

Hoping this will help you to understand
the situation of the midday meal, I remain

Yours very truly,

I have your letter of the 19th ultimo with reference to supplies for midday meals served at Whitefish Bay Indian Day School. I stated in my communication of October 19th we are prepared to allow the same amount for midday meal purposes as last year. I cannot agree with the reasoning of the teacher. I cannot understand why the teacher is asking for rolled oats. It requires time to prepare and classroom work will inevitably suffer. The Supervisor of Family Allowances has just handed me this circular letter of October 27th which should be brought to the teacher's attention.

Philip Phelan,

Dear Sir:

We the undersigned Chiefs, Councillor for members of our band meeting in the Whitefish Bay Reserve have come to a unanimous decision and resolved: That we request for a new school. We wish to ask you to take this into consideration immediately so that erection of the building or buildings be commenced as soon as possible and have it ready by this year at the next opening of schools in September.

You will readily agree that in the reports of schools that our school attendance is in remarkably good standing. There are at present thirty seven children crowded in the one class room and it is expected that there will be more of age next year.

The school is we hate to say, that it is a disgrace to our children while they are so earnest in their education to have to go to the type of school they attend to. It is built of logs and appears ready to fall off. In the winter the class room is so cold that the fire has to keep going while some of the children are half roasted and others away from the stove half frozen. The play ground is too small and too near the lake.

We have in mind a very good location for the new school and a separate building for the teacher or teachers. This building should be made so that it accommodates guests such as when we have visitors, the Indian Agent, the Doctor etc., and also that there be room enough for a medical dispensary which is taken care of by the teacher.

The new school should be a modern school with two class rooms to accommodate not less than fifty pupils with two teachers. It should have an basement so that the pupils would have a place to play in the cold winter days or in bad weather in the Spring and Fall so that they would not have to remain in the class rooms all day long.

This letter does not cover all the reasons why we need a new school. We are sending this through our Indian Agent and we are sure that he will add more to this request since he knows how necessary it is to have a new, bigger and better school.

Yours truly,

(signed) Tom Roy

Re: Shifflan Bay Indian Day School.

A letter has been received from the Chief and Councillors of the Shifflan Bay Band of Indians, requesting that a new Day School be erected to replace the old log building now in use on the Reserve.

The request I do believe is justified. The present building is of log construction and was built some 16 or more years ago. The foundation is collapsing and in a bad state of repair. Remodelling would not warrant the expenditure entailed in putting the school in a first class condition.

The school at present is over crowded, there being 38 pupils in attendance, and with an increase next year, there would not be adequate room. The school was built to accommodate 25 pupils. The matter of comfort is also of some importance and this is lacking in the present set-up.

It is believed that there will be a steady increase in attendance and a new school should be planned to take care of at least 50 pupils. This increase would also mean the addition of another teacher. The present teacher lives in the east end of the present building, which I do not think is a good arrangement. If a new school is built, quarters for the teacher should be constructed apart from the school.

The present area used as a playground is too small and if a new school were built, a location could be chosen, so as to give adequate provision for recreation.

Whitefish Bay Indian Day School

Further to our letter of April 9th, please be advised that the misunderstanding with regard to this school was caused by the fact that the councillors and yourself requested a two room school rather than the one room school originally requested by Chief Roy.

Would you please assure the council that we do intend to build a school at Whitefish Bay, either this year or next year.

There are three possibilities raised after considering your letter of April 2nd:

(a) That we erect a pre-fabricated teachers residence this year and the school next year. As you are probably aware, we are having a great deal of difficulty in getting contractors to erect schools which are located considerable distances from towns. We have already purchased four small teachers residences from a pre-fabricated construction firm and may consider doing the same at Whitefish Bay,

(b) That we construct a one room day school and residence combined,

(c) That we construct a two room day school and residence combined.
Major C.A.F. Clark, our educational Survey Officer is at present in the Yukon but is expected to be flying out shortly. Upon his return, it is our intention to send him to Kenora to further discuss with you the action which we should take with regard to this school.

Mr. Norman Paterson,
Superintendent, Indian Agency,
Kenora, Ontario

Dear Sir,

While the Department intends to build a new school on our Reserve I have been thinking if it would help the members of our band to sell some timber to the Department at this time to have it made into lumber. In this way they could save a lot more money rather than to buy lumber.

Supposing they want to buy 20,000 feet of lumber for the school @ $70.00 per thousand feet, would come to $1400.00.

Just rough figuring we would cut pine logs @ .06¢ per foot from 4 inch tops and up.

Let's average 6 inch tops 16 feet long would take 31 logs per thousand feet of lumber.

I hear A. Elders charges to make lumber @ $16.00 per thousand feet (finished lumber). 20,000 feet lumber when finished would come to $496.00. 31 logs to make a thousand feet of lumber would take 620 logs. 16 feet long @ .06¢ per foot would come to $29.76 per 1000 feet. 20,000 feet lumber would be $595.20 making a total of $1091.20.

The difference would be $305.80 which the Department would save by buying the timber from us.

I could take the contract for the 620 logs and would pay the cutters so much leaving some for defraying expenses such as skidding and piling on the road. I wish you would forward this suggestion to Mr. Neary. I think this is worth considering both for the Department and members of this Band.

Yours truly,

(sgd) Tom Roy, Chief.

Res: Whitefish Bay Indian Day School

Receipt is acknowledged of your letters dated the 3rd of March, your file 129-8-5(a) and the 9th of March, file 129-8-5(b), relative to the above noted.

The writer met Chief Tom Roy, and Mr. Peter Fenez Teacher on the Whitefish Bay Reserve yesterday and after discussing this matter fully, I would now report as undernoted.

(1) A prefabricated school (2 room) sufficient to take care of increase in attendance up to 60 pupils is desired. A separate prefabricated Teachers residence to accommodate if the need arises, a married teacher and a single assistant teacher.

(2) In former reports relative to this proposed new school, I had suggested as outlined above. There are now 40 pupils in attendance regularly and it is anticipated that there will be 6 to 8 new admissions this coming fall term. The Northwest Angle Bands 33 and 37, have Reserves just across from Whitefish Bay Reserve and each year, additional Band members are moving to this location. This means that they expect their children to be admitted to the Whitefish Bay Day School. It is considered that, taking a long view as to the needs of the new proposed school the question of attendance should be considered and it is quite probable that within 5 years the attendance at this school should reach 60 or more pupils.

(3) There is also the matter of teachers. At present Mr. Fenez the teacher is overburdened if an assistant teacher were supplied quarters of course would have to be considered. It is therefore necessary to have separate Teachorage quarters, apart from the 2 roomed school.

(4) Were it decided to go ahead with the teachorage and 2 roomed school, the first consideration is the digging of the basements. This would require I believe a bull dozer or mechanical digging equipment. Hand labour even if by Indian help would increase cost considerably.

The erection of the buildings could be economically built by say an experienced carpenter and helper with several Indians for casual labour, rough carpentry work etc.

The transportation of equipment and material would have to be made by water. A boat and barge can be procured any time at Kenora.

Local building contractors could be contacted and asked for tenders.

The aforementioned is respectfully submitted for your information.

Norman Paterson,
Superintendent,
Kenora Indian Agency

Further to our conversation regarding the plan for a one room school you brought over for me to see, I want to further my objection to the one room school as it will not suit this reserve whatever. There are at present 40 children in school. Roughly figuring there will be at least 30 or 35 of age to start going to school within the next three years—while there are only 5 to go out at that time possibly less, if they should continue going to higher grades.

We can safely assume that there will be 70 in class in three years time. To prepare for all eventualities we will have the teachers residence large enough to accommodate other people such as the nurse and other guests who are interested in Indian Welfare. Both the school Inspector and the teacher agreed that this school requires two teachers even at the present time. There are from one to grade nine in class which is really too much for one teacher to handle, no wonder they are not progressing very much.

Therefore I demand that we get the two room school and separate building for the teacher's residence.

I forgot to mention about the labour I thought I saw in the letter from Mr. Neary you showed me that there will have to be free Indian labour. I want you to forward my letter to Mr. Neary so that he may know the conditions on our Reserve. You know just as well as I do that the members of this reserve are not rich people. They have to keep going to make a living with the very tough difficulties they have in their occupation in fishing. They cannot be expected to work at the school for nothing. It is not a matter of wanting to get paid for what they have to eat too. Most of the able bodied working men are busy fishing during the summer months from which they receive good pay. I trust that you will forward this letter to Mr. Neary for his information.

Yours very truly,

(sgd) Tom Roy, Chief

While visiting the Whitefish Bay Indian Reserve on Wednesday June 23rd, the writer met Chief Tom Roy and several Band members.

I would also respectfully advise that before foundations are laid, there are many preliminaries, such as the site for the school, the acquisition of the land for the school from the Location ticket holder, type of lighting and heating plants, if inside or outside toilets, if inside toilets a disposal bed or field would have to be provided.
Re: Whitefish Bay Indian Day School

The foregoing is respectfully submitted, so that delay which may be caused by misinterpretation of your wishes in this matter, can be alleviated. Your advice would be much appreciated.

Dear Sir,

Reference the proposed two room school and the teacher's residence at the Whitefish Bay Reserve, we have inspected the site and studied the plans, and have come to the conclusion that, due to the distance from our plant and lack of information on the project, we cannot submit a tender on this work.

However, we would be pleased to do this work on a cost plus 10% basis. We feel that this would be the most satisfactory arrangement for reasons mentioned above and because of the many unforeseen factors which invariably arise when operating so far from town and because of the poor communications.

If these arrangements are satisfactory, we would have to insist on being notified in the very near future, because we would like to have the project well under way before the fall and bad weather.

It is our understanding that all materials, sub-trades, etc., other than those supplied by the North American Lumber Company, will be supplied by us. This is almost imperative in the interest of expediency.

Again, if we are to do this work, it would be desirable to have someone from the Department here for a day or two, preferably an engineer, who has sufficient authority to make spot decisions on many points which are not covered by the plans and specifications and other problems that have arisen out of local conditions.

Thanking you for this inquiry, and hoping to serve you further in this matter, we remain,

Yours truly,

Dear Mr. Neary:

In connection with your letter of recent date to Mr. Norman Patterson, Superintendent of the Kenora Indian Agency; where you ask him to send you the cost of building the new school on our Reserve and that you will ask the Council for appropriation for that purpose.

I wish to remind you what you promised me and my councilor when I was in Ottawa last May. It is over three years now since I've been after for a new school which we badly need. You must have been fully aware of it when you told me that you had the money for the school; only you were stuck to get contractors to build it.

We have the contractors ready and waiting to start any time. I spoke to them and they promised they will build it; why I am urging you to get this school built and get it done with so I don't have to keep bothering you.
all the time. It is a pity to see our children have to go back to that humble shack for a school again this year after me promising them last June we would have a new school for them. I look your promise for granted and I sincerely hope you will not disappoint us by delaying any longer. Please reply by mail.

Yours truly,
Chief Tom Roy.

SPECIFICATIONS "B"

Covering Standards of Materials and Construction for One Storey and 1½ storey Precision-Made Homes.

GENERAL

The company supplies Prefabricated panels for floors, wall portions, ceiling, gable ends and roof, and finishing materials as specified below. For distances not exceeding ten miles from Elmwood Factory we do the complete erection of all the panels.

For our Company Truck Delivery, over ten miles, an erection supervisor goes along with the house to supervise and work with from five to seven men (depending on size of house) supplied by the purchaser for one day to help erect the panels.

In rail delivery, the purchaser is responsible for trucking the panels from the car to the site and when everything is ready the erection supervisor will arrive to supervise the erection of the panels as outlined above.

Two days free labor on the part of the erector is provided for in the price of the house and the second day the erector will sort all floor bear materials and start the finishing carpenters on the proper setting of the floors.

In all cases of rail delivery the erector's fare and living expenses will be charged as an extra to contract.

Regardless of distance, the purchaser supplies all finishing materials supplied for application at the site near the supervisor.

1. WALL TO FLOOR PLACEMENT

An 8 x 8 or 8 x 10 laminated wood beam is supplied for each corner of floors, depending on size of house. The 2 x 6 wall studs are supplied for supporting centre beams. A 2 x 6 wood sill is supplied to go around the top of the concrete wall and bolts for anchoring wall to concrete. If post or block foundation is used, the 2 x 6 or 3 x 10 beams are supplied in lieu of 2 x 6 sill and anchor bolts. No post or blocks for foundation are supplied, but may be purchased at an additional charge. Three or four concrete bases with two or more holes (depending on size of house) and one coal chute are also supplied for installation in concrete wall.

2. SUB-FLOORING

Prefabricated floor sections are constructed of 2 x 6 joists at 16" centres. Sub-flooring is 1" shiplap applied diagonally with all joints cut over joists. Finish flooring is ¾ x 1½" Maple or other approved flooring is supplied for application at the site in all rooms except kitchen and bathrooms. Finish flooring in kitchen and bathroom consists of 5/16" Plywood which is applied over subflooring at the site as a base for "A" grade linoleum, which is supplied along with cement to be applied at the site.
Outside walls are prefabricated in room length panels of 2x4 studding spaced at 16" centres with single bottom and double top plate and 2x4 solid header between all studs. The sheathing is 3/4" shiplap applied horizontally or full 1/2" shiplap applied diagonally, or other approved sheathing.

Wall sections are insulated in the factory with Rockwool semi-thick batts fastened between studs before applying Standard quality minimum thickness 1/4" - 3 ply Plywood in large sheets that form a seamless wall that can be decorated in any manner you choose.

Purchaser's choice of the following sidings are supplied for application at the site; 1/2x4, 1/2x6, 3/4x8, or 3/4x10 Cedar siding or Johnsonville Cedar Grain Asbestos Siding Shingles or brick or stone veneer, or three coats of cement stucco over metal lath. All the above are applied over one ply of plain paper and one ply of tar paper, supplied for application at the site. (1/2x8 Cedar Siding is supplied with the basic siding under the specification. The other alternative sidings may be secured at an additional charge providing same are available.)

INSIDE PARTITIONS:

Prefabricated in room length panels of 2x4 studding spaced at 16" centres with single bottom and double top plate and 2x4 solid header between all studs. The same plywood in large sheets used on outside walls is applied to both sides of all interior partitions in the factory.

One storey homes have 2x6 or 2x8 ceiling joists (size determined by dimensions of house) spaced on 16" centres. One and half storey homes have 2x8 ceiling joists spaced on 16" centres. Sections have 1x2 strapping spaced on 12" centres running across the underside of the joists over which is applied Plywood in large sheets. Rockwool Insulation is supplied for insulating ceilings of one storey homes, and 1½ storey homes with unfinished attics, and for the unfinished portion of 2 storey designs with finished attics. Rockwool insulation is supplied for the sloping walls, ceilings, and inside end of the dormer bay with finished upstairs.

POOR COPY
Windows, Doors & Louvers

Window and door frames are factory made with exterior trim applied ready for fitting into openings at time of erection. Windows, storm sash and screens are factory fitted into frames. Exterior doors are equipped with combination screen and storm door, all of which are hung in frames at the factory and equipped with standard quality hardware. Inside door frames are supplied with doors fitted into same, ready for installation at the site after the house is erected. Front door is White Pine or better - minimum thickness 1 3/4". Interior doors - minimum thickness 1 3/8". Window sill, door sill materials to be of fir. Window sashes - White Pine & or Spruce, 1 3/8" minimum thickness.

Louvre ventilators are supplied for installation in attics and sections to ventilate the attic. Same are covered on inside with wire screening. All windows, doors and louvres to be of size shown on plan.

Trim & Fittings

All inside window and door casings are supplied ready cut and mitred for application at the site. Other inside casings are supplied in random lengths for application at the site after the house is erected.

Exterior trim consisting of roof and corner trim is supplied in long lengths for application after the panels are erected by the purchaser. Window and door trim, however, come completely fitted and attached to frames. Interior trim is in "Select" Pine & or Spruce & or Better.

Clothes closet and linen closet shelving members are supplied cut to length for installation at the site. Same may be supplied for rods in closets and vestibule.

Kitchen

Kitchen cupboards are supplied completely built and ready to install. Kitchen sink is supplied under this specification, but may be purchased at an additional charge so that it is fitted into the cupboard in the factory. Top of cupboard to be mounted. Hardware, cupboard pulls are supplied for application after installation.

A stock size medicine cabinet is supplied to fit into or hang over bathtub in bathroom and is equipped with shelf, clock, mirror.

Foundation:

Brick or block, either brick or concrete block, may be supplied within 10 miles of Winnipeg. If the building site is beyond 10 miles a credit will be allowed toward building cost of $2.00 per square foot based on a fuel length chimney from heating under case to floor in basement to a point 2' above the top of the house. Fuel to consist of 2,500 lbs. fire, bricks or concrete blocks, lime and sand.
FINISHING MATERIAL FOR SECOND FLOOR WITH FINISHED UPSTAIRS.

Sub-flooring of 1" Shiplap is supplied in long lengths for application by the purchaser after house is erected and electrical wiring and heating ducts are in place. All second storey partitions are prefabricated of the same materials as first floor partitions. Collar ties are cut to size for installation after the house is erected. Blocking to place between collar ties and rafters to form a nailing surface for plywood on ceilings so supplied in linear footage. Plywood for ceiling finish is supplied in 4x8 sheets for application by the purchaser. Moulding to go in all corners and ceilingline of all second storey is supplied in long lengths. Vapor Seal Paper is supplied to go between the interior finish and joists. All cupboards and bedroom doors are supplied. Flooring of the same quality as downstairs is supplied.

Unfinished staircase:

Sub-flooring is supplied as above and knee walls are put in place.

STAIRCASE

Are constructed of 12" x 12", Fir stock housed out to receive treads, risers and wedges. Treads are of E.O. Fir or Oak or Pine according if stimulated. Risers in all cases are of clear K.D. 1". The lower and upper flights are factory assembled complete with risers, treads and cove moulding under nosing. The winding treads, risers and treads are supplied packaged in bundles for delivery which is installed after upper and lower main flights are finished. No stairwell, newly and bathrooms regulations. Stairs shall not be less than 7' wide, measured from face of string to face of string and width of tread included. The landing shall not be less than 10'. Stringers shall have solid treads top and bottom - minimum effective depth of wooden stringer shall be 3/4" - maximum rise 6" - minimum clear width 3'6".

LIBRARY:

No additional charge is made for delivery up to 10 miles from Elmwood factory. For distances over 10 miles a delivery charge based on size of house is made on carriage basis. Rates in accordance with size of house purchased.

Memorandum:

DIRECTOR,
LANDS AND DEVELOPMENT SERVICES BRANCH.

Two-room Indian Day Schools - Manitoba District.

(1) Lake St. Martin Indian Day School,
Portage la Prairie Agency

Arrangements have now been completed to erect a standard two-room Indian Day School with attached teachers' residence on the above Reserve. The Department has purchased the necessary materials and Mr. Helgason, a local builder is supplying the labour.

We have received a request from our Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies for Manitoba for one of your Engineers to visit this school about once every fortnight during the course of construction. While we realize that you cannot take the responsibility for the erection of this building, we would appreciate receiving the advice of your Engineers during the course of the building.

While our Indian Superintendents are quite prepared to assume the responsibility for the erection of one-room Indian Day Schools, they feel that some assistance and advice is required for the erection of tworoom schools.

(2) Whitefish Bay Indian Day School, Kenora Agency

Originally it was intended to erect a prefabricated two-room school and a separate prefabricated teachers' residence on this Reserve. However, due to delays which have occurred, it has been decided to erect a standard
two-room Indian Day School with attached teachers' residence during the 1949-50 fiscal year.

We would ask that your Branch assume the responsibility for the erection of this school. It is felt that due to the comparative isolation of this Reserve (some 40 miles from Kenora, Ontario) that the normal procedure should be followed with regard to advertising for tenders, etc.,

Our reason for advising you at this early date of our decision in this regard is to enable you to have Mr. Gow or one of his staff visit this Reserve, to prepare the necessary site plan and thus be ready to advertise for tenders early in the Spring of 1949.

Acting Director.

Following up our conversation by telephone this morning relative to the tenders submitted covering the erection of the Day School at the Whitefish Bay Indian Reserve, I would now report as follows:

This morning I contacted Major James Forbes of Keewatin, and confidentially asked his opinion of the capability and integrity of Mr. E. Florstrand, who has submitted a tender on this project. He is also highly recommended by Mr. Andrew Olson, well known business man of Keewatin, who advises that in his opinion Mr. Florstrand would do a good job.

Memorandum

Re: Construction of Indian Two-room Day School, Whitefish Bay, Kenora Indian Agency, Ontario

Two lump sum tenders for construction of the above were received through public advertisement.

The contractors tendering, and the amounts of their tenders were as follows:

(1) Simmons Construction Co., Winnipeg, Manitoba. - - - $50,990.00

(2) S. Florstrand, Box 58, Keewatin, Ont. - - - $37,934.20

Only the first named supplied the required security deposit.

Due to the difference in cost between the two tenders, we initiated investigations regarding the lowest tenderer S. Florstrand, through the Indian Superintendent at Kenora.

Superintendent Paterson has now replied advising that he carried out confidential enquiries with the Mayor of Keewatin, and a number of business men of that town, who gave him very satisfactory reports regarding Florstrand's integrity and ability. This contractor, however when tendering omitted to forward his security deposit and technically could be considered ineligible. However, in view of the standing he appears to hold in the community, and his low tender, this office wired Florstrand yesterday telling him that we were prepared to recommend acceptance of his tender provided he furnished the security deposit required. He replied by wire this morning that he will forward a marked cheque for ten per cent of his tender price, by air mail tomorrow.

On the basis of the above, a recommendation to Council is being prepared, and will be processed through Mr. Nason immediately.

Chas. H. Buck,

Several visits have been made to the school and more especially contact has been made, owing to the commencement of the new day school under construction. M. Benidickson, M.P.,
House of Commons,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir,

Re: Chapel Site at Regina Bay, near Sioux Narrows, Ont.

I have been trying to secure Title to an Island on Regina Bay, on the Lake of the Woods, for a Chapel Site. My application cannot be filed under Ont. Land Act till I produce evidence that the owner of the building is not opposed, or else surrenders title to the building.

The said building is the Whitefish Bay Indian Day School owned by Department of Mines and Resources, Indian Affairs Branch. It is now being replaced by new two-room school house.

By letter of Dec. 30, 1948, Mr. Phelan was informing our charge-d'affaire, at Ottawa, that the policy of the Department in such case was to turn over any unused building to War Assets Corporation. This would further delay my endeavour to make use of this Island for missionary purposes.

This log house is of very little commercial value but I would like to be offered first chance, or a document showing that it is surrendered to me, or rather, to the Oblate Fathers so that I could go ahead with my plans to secure Title to this Island.

Yours very truly,

(Sgd) A. Laclelle O.K.I.
Mr. B. F. Neary,
Education Service,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Booth Building,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Mr. Neary,

Re: St. Mary's Indian School

I attach hereto copy of a letter I have received from the Rev. A. Lacelle of St. Mary's Indian School, Kenora, respecting the matter I discussed with you on the telephone.

If the old building referred to is to be abandoned, I can appreciate it that it is desirable to find some short-cut, if at all possible, if there is no reason why the Oblate Fathers should not be aided in obtaining early title in connection with their application to the Provincial Department of Lands and Forests.

Yours very truly,

November 27, 1949.

W. N. Denidickson, Esq., M.P.,
House of Commons,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Whitefish Bay Indian Day School.

Dear Sir:

I have just acknowledged your letter of November 15 and as I advised you in our telephone conversation, I am referring this matter at once to our field officials. I have checked the files here and find that the Department purchased a parcel of land comprising 1.45 acres from an Indian owner for school purposes. However, this property is close to the present day school and was purchased to give additional playground facilities.

It will be necessary, therefore, to make certain that the old school property is not also required in connection with the operation of this new two-room school.

When a reply is received, I will advise you immediately.

Sincerely yours,

Bernard F. Henry,
Superintendent of Education.

Kenora, November 14th, 1949

Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario

Re: Whitefish Bay Indian Day School

Receipt is acknowledged of your letter dated the 31st ultimo, files 445-5(E) & 445-1, relative to requirements for the teacherage of the above school.

During an inspection trip to the Reserve on Sunday November 6th, I was advised by Mr. Swen Florstrand, Contractor, that with weather favourable he thought that the school would be ready for occupation about the end of January 1950.

The work has been delayed on several occasions due to exceptionally bad weather and previous to running cement foundations they were held up for reinforcing steel.

To date they have made fair progress and are at present erecting roof and covering. The weather has again turned for the worse with intermittent rain and sleet. This with the near advent of freeze up will no doubt hinder the work.

Mr. Florstrand also advised that once the building is covered work should proceed regardless of weather conditions.

Please find attached in triplicate, Requisition for material for the Whitefish Bay Indian Day School teacherage.

Norman Paterson
Superintendent, Indian Agency.

With the advent of the new Day School on this Reserve, the writer would like your advice on the several matters concerning the proper conduct and purposes for which the school building may be used outside of regular school days.

I am attaching copy of a letter received from Mr. N. Paterson, Superintendent, Kenora Agency, regarding use of school buildings for other purposes. Before replying, I would appreciate your comment on my interpretation of such usage.

In general, I think school buildings should be used for concerts, etc., provided that whoever is in charge of the activity ensures that the classroom is left clean and desks, etc., restored to their proper places. In this particular case I cannot see the need for 100 chairs. The most that would be used at any time would be 50. However, I do not anticipate that the Educational Division will supply these at all.

Where any Religious body has desired to use schools under my jurisdiction in the past for church services I have allowed them to be so used. The only rules laid down in this regard were first: That the school should be available to any denomination that had adherents on the Reserve, secondly: Nothing permanent was to be erected and the classroom was to be restored for teaching purposes after the service.

Apparently some action has been taken at Morson without Mr. Paterson being advised. This should not be done, otherwise the Superintendent, who is definitely in charge is ignored.

Kindly let me have your observations on my general rulings.

Yours,

Sir,

I have recently returned from a trip to some of our
Indian settlements east of here, I beg to say a few words about the schools
at them, Jackfish Island, on Lake Temagami, and Big Flat.

At the former place, the school-house badly needs to be raised—it
having settled a good deal during the last two years—and shingled since
the old shingles, now more than ten years old, being rotten—, as also
to be whitewashed inside and outside. Already two years ago did I call
the attention of the Indian Agent J. D. Donnelly to this; but for some
reason or other, nothing has been done in the matter so far (I was up
there a month ago), the school having been built without any aid from
the Department, these people deserve—I think—they help from the

I am sorry to say the teacher, Mr. J. A. Bliss does not keep his school

I have also been told—after I had left Jackfish Island—that he does

The Secretary Dept. of Indian Affairs
Ottawa.

Dear Sir,

I write in the name of the Chiefs and Indians of the Nepigon, especially those who belong to the Sack Fish Island Reserve, and in my own name, being now in charge of these missions, asking the Dept. to have the School opened again at Sack Fish Island.

I have found a man well qualified to teach who is ready to take the School next fall, for the ordinary salary of $300.00. His education since his return from England, after passing through the elementary school training, has followed the Ottawa University Course, including Latin and Greek course, for four years.

But so many young people get discouraged and come West some fifteen years ago. He has tried to develop a liking for trapping and has combined with the Indians of the Nepigon for about ten or twelve years; he has married this Indian woman and does not intend to return among white people. I think that it is a real chance to have joined such a man as teacher.

In summer there are always from twenty to twenty-five children of school age, and the rest of the year eight to twelve. School would be opened in summer and holidays would take place in winter.
I am convinced that more families would remain at Lake Fish Lake in winter if the school was opened.

The schoolhouse, which is a log building of 29 x 19 ft., would need some repainting though. It has to be shingled. There should be a floor over the logs to keep the little ones from walking on the logs with their shoes. It would take nine thousand (9000) shingles that cost $4.25 each. But certainly, the freight from Port Arthur to Lake Fish would be at least two thousand. We could also use lumber and fencing common boards to make roughsheds, the stair case, and a partition in the attic.

I do not know exactly how much it would cost to have the work done. I figure that it would cost about $30.00 or $35.00. With a little paint for the desks and blackboard, paintbrushes, some pine (there is a pine store), the whole amount might be $125.00 or $130.

Most of the material could be bought only near winter, but I think we could manage to open the school in September if the Lake Fish people were willing and able to help. The school would be located at the lake's edge, so as to be convenient to the settlers' homes.

I was asked by the Chiefs of the Lake Fish to come to a formal meeting to discuss this matter, but as I would have to travel a considerable distance...
that this letter will be sufficient.

Hoping to receive a favorable answer as soon as possible, for I will be away a great part of summer, visiting the Missions so that I may take the necessary steps to be ready to enter the school in Sept. 1908.

With humble regards,
