Had I been consulted, I do not think that I should have been very favourable to the idea of sending a half-breed young lady, of tender years, of no great academic standing, and of still less professional preparation, to open a new school at Whitesand, far from parental oversight of any kind. To bring along successfully a new school requires an ability of a high order, while, to my mind, the task of starting off properly the neophyte along his educational path is the most difficult task facing the ordinary teacher. Fewer teachers of experience are capable of doing this really well than is generally supposed. How much less, then, can it be done by teachers of such meagre preparation. However, it might have been difficult, in view of the remote location, and the none-too-promising quarters, to secure a really good qualified lady teacher, and the Department having engaged Miss McGuire, I should be most loath to do anything towards her removal, especially as her work is quite as good as that done by white teachers of equal qualification, or should I have rather said equal lack of qualification.

Dear Mr. Burk,

I am sorry that I have not been able to discover any teacher in this locality desirous of accepting the Whitesand Indian Day School.

Actually there is no teacher unemployed locally, but if there were I should, if consulted, strongly dissuade any white young lady from going there.

The living conditions there are entirely unsuitable for white young ladies. The school building is easily among the poorest I see anywhere, and the Indians are more than usually backward.

If I knew of any male teacher unemployed, I would mention the school to him, but I doubt very much if any male teacher would consider the school as anything but a very temporary proposition.

Because, besides the conditions outlined above, the salary, (Sixty Dollars per month), is most unattractive. The enrolled strength at Whitesand is about equal, (or greater) to that of the neighbouring schools, all of which are allotted greater salaries.

In my opinion, which is given for what it is worth, you have been extremely lucky to have Miss McGuire stay at Whitesand so long. Only the fact that she was partly Indian allowed her to do so, and, as you know, she refused to stay there any longer, and only returned, (after the lapse of a year), because she had been unable to get anything else to do. The male teacher we had in her place was not too greatly inclined to remain there for another year. If I had my way, this being the most unattractive school in your Agency, I would make its salary the greatest.

Yours very sincerely,

Sgd. (W. J. Greening)

A large majority of the Whitesand Band have been living on the Transcontinental railway between Longlac, Ont., and Armstrong, Ont. The male members are working as section hands, for the railway and are paid at the rate of .50¢ per hour. The Roadmaster, Mr. J. Pederson, very kindly offered to convey the Treaty Party from Longlac to Armstrong, via gas car, in order not to cause any delay by the Indians leaving their work, to go to the Whitesand reserve for their Treaty money. This saved a great deal of time and gave us the opportunity to interview a great many of these Indians personally. The Can. Nat'l Railways officials were extremely pleased that we were able to pay these Indians in this manner and not cause any delay in the track work.

A separate letter will be forwarded later regarding the number of children along the track, who are not receiving any schooling.

For the past several years we have not notified the Indians when we would pay treaty, as they invariably wasted a great deal of time from their work. The only protest we received regarding this method of payment, was at Heron Bay, at the Pic Reserve. The majority of the Indians at this point are loading boats, cutting pulpwood and rafting.

At all reservations and settlements, the Indians were working, with the exception of the old people.

J.O. Burk,
Indian Agent.

Ottawa, June 24, 1930.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 21st instant, relative to the opening of the Whitesand Indian Day School and nominating of the services of Miss McGuire for the position as teacher.

In this connection it is noted that the council house, which is to be used as a temporary classroom, has been repaired and made ready for use for school purposes, also that temporary quarters attached to the council house have been erected for the teacher's use. As the Indians are anxious that this school be commenced as early as possible, the Department will approve of the appointment of Miss McGuire as teacher, with salary at the rate of $40 per teaching month. Please inform her of her appointment, and arrange with her to proceed to the school and commence duties as early in July, next, as possible. You should give her any assistance you can upon commencing duties. It is hoped that this school will meet with success and that there will be a good attendance of the Indian children residing on the Whitesand Reserve. Please advise the Department later of the date on which Miss McGuire opens the school, also her Christian name and any particulars regarding her qualifications.

Your obedient servant,

GENERAL REMARKS

Under this heading the Inspector should report upon the general management of the school and offer any suggestions for improvement he may wish to make.

The results being secured here might warrant the school being graded as a fair to good average Indian Day School.

Had I been consulted, however, I do not think that I should have been very favourable to the idea of sending a half-breed young lady, of tender years, of no great academic standing, and of still less professional preparation to open a new school; it was, and is, far from parental oversight of any kind. To bring along successfully a new school requires an ability of a high order while, to my mind, the task of starting off properly the neophyte along his educational path is the most difficult task facing the ordinary teacher. Fewer teachers of experience are capable of doing this really well, how much less then, can be done by teachers of such meagre preparation. However, it might have been difficult, in view of the remote location, and the none-too-promising quarters, to secure a really good qualified lady-teacher, and, the Department having engaged Miss Macaire, I should be most loath to do anything towards her removal—especially as her work is quite as good as that done by white teachers of equal qualification, or should I have rather said equal lack of qualification.

As a result of a carefully considered investigation of these Indian Day Schools (including a discussion of them with such other inspectors as I meet from time to time who visit such schools) I find that there are several reasons for their failure to do work of as high an order as the expenditure and care lavished upon them by the Department would seem to merit. I have spoken of two of these reasons in my recent report upon the Lake Helen Indian Day School. While I am far from denying that, occasionally, an unqualified teacher will be found doing better work than a qualified (inferior) teacher, nevertheless I should like at this time to claim for the unqualified teacher at least a part of the blame for this deficiency.

GENERAL REMARKS

Under this heading the Inspector should report upon the general management of the school and offer any suggestions for improvement he may wish to make.

I think that Miss McGuire is doing good work. Compared with the work of other teachers more highly paid, I think that Miss McGuire's work, both on account of the quality of her work and the unattractive school conditions—location and building—warrants a higher net salary than fifty-four dollars per month.

Miss McGuire is a very skilled worker in beads and silk. Indian silk work, I have been told, is rapidly disappearing, while the work in beads is much less widespread. If a few dollars could be spared to provide material, I am sure that Miss McGuire could have good work done in these lines at Whitesand.

There is one pupil at this school who is very deaf, and who is securing very little advantage, (except in manual arts) from her attendance at school. She ought to be sent to the School for the Deaf at Belleville, I think, or to some similar institution. She has some little hearing left and talks very readily. She could be easily trained at Belleville.

This building is in very poor shape.

When we arrived at Whitesand, we were disappointed to find that the teacher was away, as we had planned upon residing upon the floor of the school building. We had no difficulty, however, in entering the school. We had simply to remove a pane of glass, which was "glazed" with a couple of hooks, and thus enter the school. There is absolutely no security for anything stored in the school building.

In order to keep out the cold in the winter, (when the temperature may fall to forty or more below,) the teacher has sheets of ordinary brown wrapping paper tacked to the log walls. It is quite possible to no enclose the building and put ones hand between the logs, thus perforating the paper which is the only thing between the occupants and sixty or seventy degrees of frost.

GENERAL REMARKS

Under this heading the Inspector should report upon the general management of the school and offer any suggestions for improvement he may wish to make.

When we reached Whitesand, it happened that Miss McQuire was away from the Reserve. Her services had been requisitioned as matron with an escort-taking Julia Maclean from MacRiver to MacDiarmid. Julia, an Indian girl, had had serious fits, and was very violent, and Miss McQuire was the only suitable woman available to look after her.

I am thoroughly satisfied with Miss McQuire's work and am certain that her absence from school was unavoidable and in the best interests of the Department.

I think that Mr. VanHatten may be expected to do really good work at Whitesand, if one might judge from the progress already made.

In this connection, might attention be called to the disparity of salary at Whitesand with that paid at any other school in this district. The attendance at McIntyre Bay, Gull Bay and Whitesand, and the qualification of the respective teachers is as follows: McIntyre Bay: 21, No professional certificates, but considerable experience with Indian children; Gull Bay: 20, Interim Second Class (Ontario); Whitesand: 19, Interim First Class (Ontario). In view of the conditions, it should have been the highest.

If a suitable teacher cannot be secured for next year, it might be advisable to send the children in to Fort William, or some other Residential School.

Your letter of Dec. 9, to Rev. Richards, concerning teachers at Whitefish School was referred to me for answer. I have the honor to report that the very small average attendance during June quarter last was occasioned by the Indians being nearly all absent with their families in the sugar bush.

The attendance at this school at the best of times is not what it should be and is occasioned by the very lax interest taken in education by the parents of the children.

I would recommend that the Indians be given one more chance to keep up the attendance at this school and if they fail to do so that it be closed and the amount it costs to carry on the day school at this place be transferred to an Industrial School with the understanding that it educates a certain number of the children from this school at the regular rate per capita.

Dear Sir,

For some time past I have been in correspondence with Indian Agent H.C. L. D. Sims of Manitouining in regard to the school situated on Whitefish Lake Indian Reserve. With letters dated January 1st, February 1912 - No. 284-20, informing me that the department intends to set up a new school on the reserve with a view to the teacher whom it may open, and that it has even advertised for tenders to that effect.

In the former letter he was kind enough to say: "The Department hopes you will be in a position to nominate a competent teacher to fill the vacancy at the school before long."

That remark, somewhat encouraged me to put an advertisement in a paper that a teacher was wanted at this school, a female teacher who I have received five applications one of the applicants being a widow, Mrs. Burnett of Willow Creek. In her first letter she says: "I am a school teacher for twelve years previous to my marriage having taught in some of the best schools in the County of Renfrew and being very good for understanding the Indian people. On receipt of this letter I explained further the situation in the Whitefish Lake school. Whereupon she answered: I am sorry to say that I do not think it best to accept your school. It is too far from a depot and so inconvenient as well as a boarding place that I do not think I am strong enough for such a place, particularly at this season of the year."
Sudbury, Ont., 190

I hoped this lady would take the school; she would have been just the person wanted.

The other three applicants are young ladies, probably.

I am quite convinced that they would either not take the position when told of the situation or if they became ill, would not stay and I told them so in a most tactful manner.

Let us drop the matter.

Now, sir, allow me to make a suggestion. Would it not be more advantageous for the Department and for the children of that Reserve at least, to do what was done in the case of those in New Manitouwans? The children were sent to the Wikwemikong Industrial School and the teachers spent their time to keep a teacher appointed there at that institution. I think it is now too late to find time, so show the wisdom of the Department by doing in the matter. But still the Wikwemikong Industrial School will be at the fish station; it will be easy to send the children there.

I thought it proper to propose this plan to the Department etc., and contract for the proposed school building at Whitefish Lake as soon as possible.

I am, dear Sir,

Yours respectfully,

(Rev.) J. Specht, S.J.

Dear friend Mr Benson,

Among other Indian Missions, I have charge of the Whitefish Lake Reserve near Sudbury, Ontario and of Beanage, near North Bay. Dear Sir,

Allow me a few words of explanation about the Whitefish Lake School. Some five weeks ago, I wrote to Mr. Benson, but received no answer—

Last winter, during an interview with Agent R. Lewis, of Manitowaning, I told him: "If we build a comfortable building, where school could be held, will you give us a teacher, for Whitefish Lake Reserve?"—Yes.—was his answer.

Upon this promise, we have made great sacrifices and have succeeded in building a chapel, that can be used, both partly for a class-room, and partly for the teacher's residence. I was somewhat disappointed when I saw your answer (Letter No. 15-1715/1, Aug 1st) to Miss Fitzpatrick's application.—I hope that you will assign your a teacher for that Reserve.

There are 34 children of school age, and they are all within ¼ mile from the school hill. The children are all bright and intelligent, and their school can be made one of the most
Benefit of all the Indian Reserves. I know
the schools of Sagamook, Butler, Shishigaming
(the anglican school), South Bay, Dokes Reserve etc.
cannot be compared to the Whitefish Lake school
for the number and talent of the pupils, and
they are granted a teacher.

Moreover, the Indians, who have worked so
hard this winter and this spring (cutting and
saving logs, etc., for their future school) are so anxious
to have a school that they will be infinitely
disappointed, if they are not given a teacher.

I understand that the Department will not build
any school during the war. It was on account
of that decision, we build the school ourselves.
For the desks and stories (working and stories)
may I suggest that the Department let us
use those of the former abandoned school of
Beaverage? The Indians will never go to
live on the barren and windy pointe of Beaverage;
they have already settled in Yuletide and Charles-
wood creek—those places are fine, useless
being spoiled by the dampness of the forsaken
building. Why not make use of them
for the immense betterment of our Indians?
If it were the pleasure of the Department I would gladly attend to the transfer of those books and stories from Beauce to Whitefish Lake.

I wrote to Our Agent Lewis, and kindly reminded him of his promise. I hope all will be arranged satisfactorily.

Since January, I have given all my free time and energy to the preparation of that Whitefish Lake School. I tramped in the deep snow to cut logs, I carried the heavy lumber, timber and planks; I dug at the foundations etc etc. I hope my strenuous efforts will not be vain.

With all confidence in your management,

Yours respectfully,

Ladies:

We, the undersigned, members of White Fish Lake Reservation, do hereby assert our grievance concerning the insufficiency of our day Public School.

I. The present system in the teaching of our children is out of date, i.e.; The prayers and the rudiments of our Catholic Church is being taught by our school teacher, Miss Tillie Patrick, and that is in our Indian tongue, consequently our children do not at all make any progress to attain the English language, which is our main object to learn in establishing the school among our children.

II. The hours are not regular in calling the children to school when the bell rings, some time 10 o'clock in the morning, and dismissing them at the hour of 11 o'clock, (A.M.) In the afternoon at the hour of two o'clock, the bell rings, they are dismissed again at the hour of 3 o'clock.

III. No proper school text books are used in teaching the children. It is all about the Catholic religion. We must have the regular course of Ontario public school instruction, prescribed for the Ontario Protestant Schools.

IV. The School teacher shall be an English person purely. Protestant need necessarily not be barred. He should not teach religion in the school. Of course ordinarily he should read the form of prayer established in the Indian School Register, both at the opening and the same closing of the school in each day. Our present teacher Miss Patrick must be removed for incompetency.
V. We Indians, of this White Fish Lake Reserve exclude the Roman Catholic Priest in the appointment of School teachers, that he does not in any form or shape interfere with our Public School.

VI. Henceforth, we give the Indian Department of Ottawa in the appointment of School Teacher, for our Public School.

VII. Considering our present surroundings, all English speaking neighbors, therefore our Tribe must be Anglicized eventually absorbed into the English race, it becomes us as a band of Indians in Council called in due form to adopt the foregoing items.

Moved by James Nootoktai, seconded by Joseph Penay, that we, as Band of White Fish Lake Reservation adopt the foregoing clauses and items in their respective form and meaning; In doing so, we do not fight against our Catholic religion; only the sole intent to establish an efficient public day school for our children, therefore, we entrust the entire confidence upon the Indian Department to possess the sole power in the appointment of our school teacher;

Therefore, our Council humbly pray that this shall be rectified by the Department of Indian affairs.

Unanimously carried.

Sir,

In reply to Official Letter No. 151716/1 of the 4th Instant, with regard to the complaints made by the Indians at Whitefish Lake in regard to the school on their reserve, I have the honor to report that I visited Whitefish Lake Reserve on the 12th Instant, and took this matter up with both the teacher and Indians, and as far as I could learn the Indians have not very much ground for complaints. The only complaints the Indians could make were that the teacher taught the pupils their prayers in the Indians language and that her hours for teaching were not regular. Miss Fitzpatrick admitted that the prayers were taught in the Indian language, but that the hours for teaching were regular, and that she had a time table for the class-room which she follows, a copy of which I enclose herewith.

I might state that it is my opinion that most of the trouble started over the teacher not being in favour of the Indians holding their council meeting in the church which is used as a class-room also, and the Indians have taken it into their heads to have the Department discharge her.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs, Indian Agent.
Ottawa, Ont.
Ottawa, March 21, 1919.

Sirs,

In further reference to the letter from yourself and other Indians of the Whitefish Lake Reserve complaining of the manner in which the school is conducted by Miss Fitzpatrick, the teacher, I beg to say that, as a result of the inquiries made, the Department does not consider that you were justified in making the complaints referred to.

I. No fault should be found with Miss Fitzpatrick in endeavouring to teach the prayers and rudiments of the Catholic religion to the children in their native tongue.

II. A regular time table is followed.

III. The text books authorized by the Department of Education for the Province of Ontario are used in this school.

IV. Miss Fitzpatrick is a Canadian of Irish extraction and Mr. Inspector Finn, who visited this school as late as the 21st ultimo, reports that she is doing satisfactory work. The appointment of Miss Fitzpatrick was made by the Department.

The Anglicization of Indian children must naturally take considerable time, as they have no opportunity of using the English language in their homes.

MEMORANDUM:

MR. SCOTT,

A request has been received from Miss Annie T. Ladouer, teacher of the Whitefish Lake (R.C.) Indian Day School, for an increase of $50.00 in her salary.

Miss Ladouer was appointed teacher of this school on September 1st, 1920, at a salary of $500. She also receives bonus at the rate of $150. A total of $650. She has a third class professional certificate and a second class non-professional, and has had 6 years' experience, 3 of which were in Indian schools.

The Separate School Inspector, in his report dated May 19th last, states as follows:

"This teacher seems to mean well and will do for this Indian school. As far as knowledge is concerned, she is alright, but she is very peculiar. She takes great pains in forcing the Indian children to come clean and neat to school. She seems earnest enough, but she is peculiar and would not do in any other school of mine. She certainly makes these children do what she says. The school is so far away from Sudbury and so isolated that it may be difficult to keep a good teacher."

There is an enrollment of 25 pupils, with an average attendance of 18.

It is difficult to get a teacher for this school, and I would recommend that she be retained for another year, and that, if you agree, she be granted an increase of $50.00 from the 1st of September, next. She is doing fair work, and is able to keep up a good attendance.

Sir:

I have the honour to enclose herewith a copy of a resolution by the chief and members of the Whitefish Lake Band requesting the Department to dispense with the services of Miss Annie T. Ladoucer as teacher at their school.

With regard to this resolution I have the honour to report that I was called to Whitefish Lake by the Indians as there was trouble between the teacher and the Indian parents, and when I visited the school on the 8th instant, I found the school closed and the teacher had herself locked in the residential portion of the school building and after having some little difficulty in gaining an entrance to the building I managed to have an interview with her in connection with school matters which she explained to me that it was all the parents fault as she was still doing good teaching in the class-room, but the parents had refused to send their children to school, therefore, the school had been closed during the current week.

On looking over the school register I noticed that the pupils had not advanced in standard since Miss Ladoucer took charge of the school, and the Indian parents informed me that she does not teach regular hours and that their children are not advancing any in education, and that they will not send their children to school any more if Miss Ladoucer is left in charge of the school.

As there has been contention between Miss Ladoucer and the Indians since she took charge of the school, and it has now reached the point where I cannot put up with her any longer, therefore, I would most respectfully recommend that the Department dispense with her services immediately and the school be closed until after the midwinter holidays, or until such time as the services of a qualified teacher can be procured.

Dear Sir:

After driving from Sudbury to visit Whitefish Lake Indian School I was hindered five miles from the school by two bridges which had been swept away by the floods. Circumstances demanded that I reach the school so I hired a canoe and an Indian guide, who as I found out later, was about half drunk.

I found the school not in operation. The register showed that no one had attended since March 3rd. The teacher, Mrs. Ladouceur, was there however and the building and class room in good clean shape. The door was locked.

The teacher claims that the Indian people will not send their children. The chief acknowledges this. They will not send their children and what the reason is I don't know and couldn't find out. I understand that it is not due to any punishment that she may have given them, however, while I cannot definitely prove so yet it appears from what I hear, that she is at least "strange and queer" to say the least. She claims that a Miss Lavallee of South Bay has written the Indian Chief and others and this has caused the Indians to turn against her. She further claims that the Indians say that they closed the school themselves. It is a question if this is true. It is hard to say who is to blame.

If Miss Lavallee did write, and if the Indians want her, then she should not be sent to them for fear that the Indians will consider that their wishes in teachers should be law. I told the chief that the Department of Indian Affairs engaged and hired the teachers and that the Indians cannot expect to have any say in the matter of teachers.

Mrs. Ladouceur cannot leave with the bridges down. It is a reasonable fear that the Indians might dump her trunk in the lake for there is no doubt they hate her.

The teacher claims that the Indians have tried to break in on her. She never leaves the school.

Sir,

The Department is in receipt of confidential information concerning Mrs. Ladoucer, the teacher of the Whitefish Lake Indian Day School. This lady has been acting strangely of late and keeps herself at present locked in the school and is not giving any service to the Department or to the Indian Band. The Indian children are prohibited from attending school by their parents, and there is rather a hostile feeling against her. I understand she would be glad to leave the Reserve if someone with the written authority of the Department would remove her and her effects under protection to Naughton Station.

It is considered useless to allow Mrs. Ladoucer to remain any longer in charge of this school, and I have, therefore, to request that you will proceed at an early date to the school and take charge of removing herself and property to Naughton Station. Any expenses incurred for this purpose will be paid upon receipt of properly certified vouchers covering the expenditure. We will not be responsible for her after she arrives at Naughton Station. Kindly attend to this matter as soon as possible and inform the Department when you have succeeded in removing her safely.

The Department understands that the Indians are anxious to obtain Miss Priscilla Lavallee, as teacher, but authority has recently been granted, as per official letter to you of the 8th instant, for her transfer to the Kabinini Indian Day School for the next school year, beginning September 1, 1922. The Band at Whitefish Lake have acted in a rather high-handed manner of late and should not be permitted to take any unauthorized action in connection with school matters. We will, therefore, not accede to the Indians' request in this regard, and the school at Whitefish Lake can remain closed, as it may be necessary to leave these Indians without a teacher in order that they will appreciate one when such is appointed.

If you consider that any balance of salary is due Mrs. Ladoucer, you should forward a voucher for the amount you consider she is entitled to.

We are anxious to get rid of her services at as early a date as possible in order to prevent any further trouble. I might inform you confidentially that there are strong reasons for doubting her sanity, and she should be removed by you to Naughton Station with little delay as possible.

Your obedient servant,

Referring to conversation with you while in the Department on Saturday, last, I have to inform you that your appointment as teacher of the Whitefish Lake Indian Day School for the coming school year is approved. The salary allowed you will be at the rate of $80 per teaching month. As you have been informed, there is living accommodation provided. There were multiple buildings when the former teacher gave up duties, but it might be advisable for you to take a quantity of bedding, linen, etc. The nearest railway station to the school is Saguenay - about four and a half miles, at which point you can obtain your supplies. You should be at the school and ready to begin duties on or about September 1st, next. Besides teaching duties, if you perform your own janitor services, salary for same will also be allowed.

The local Indian Agent is Mr. R. J. Lewis, Manitowaning. He, however, resides at a considerable distance from the school. We are informing him of your appointment and requesting him, during his visits to the reserve, to give you every assistance he can. Should there by any supplies required either for the classroom or for your living quarters, I would request that you prepare a list and forward same to the Department. It is hoped that you will meet with every success as teacher at Whitefish Lake.

If you proceed to the school via Ottawa and have time, it would be advisable for you to call at the Department for any further information you may require.

Dear Mrs. Burnett:

It is entirely probable that you are quite happy at the Whitefish Lake Indian Day School and are not desirous of a transfer, but I should like to give a move to the young lady who is teaching at the Maniwaki Indian Day School, in Quebec. I write to enquire if you would like to trade schools with her. The same salary would be allowed.

The Maniwaki Indian Day School is one and a half miles from the white village of Maniwaki. There is no residence attached to the school and you would board in the white village. The class is heavier than you have had, as there are from 20 to 30 in attendance, depending upon the season of the year. The Indian Agent lives at Maniwaki. I thought it probable that you might like a school closer to your home and that an opportunity to live with white folks again would be attractive. Please let me know at your earliest convenience if you would like to consider this transfer. To refresh your memory I may say that Maniwaki is 88 miles north of Ottawa and is on the railroad.

Yours very truly,

Sir:

With reference to Departmental Letter No. 19-8-1 of February 12th, last, to the effect that the Department was approving of the appointment of Miss Irene Donlon, of North Bay, Ont., as teacher at the Whitefish Lake Indian Day School to begin duties on the 19th ultimo; I have the honour to report that I paid this school a visit on the 16th instant, and found that the school had been re-opened on the 19th ultimo by Miss Donlon.

Sir:

With reference to Departmental letter No. 19-8/1 of the 3rd of September and previous correspondence, I refer to the state of conditions existing at the Whitefish Lake Indian School. I have the honour to report that I have made an investigation of this matter and would report that the school has not been re-opened as the Indians have refused to send their children to school on account of the conduct of the children during the summer holidays. During the last year Miss Kinoshagmeg seem to conduct herself in an upright manner, and was a capable teacher, but it would appear that during the summer holidays she had been living with an Indian at Whitefish Lake in an immoral manner. She gave absolute denial to me of this accusation by the Indians, stating that it was false, but I knew that after the school closed for the summer holidays she did not return to her home in Tremikong. She was willing to return to the school but the Indians refused to send any of the children to school on account of her misconduct, but on questioning all the Indians regarding her conduct there did not seem to be any of them who would actually swear that she was living an immoral life, and I am led to believe that the Indians are more to blame than the teacher.

I have now learned that Miss Kinoshagmeg has now been removed to the Indian women's hospital at Leech Lake against her will, and therefore, the appointment of a new teacher will be necessary without delay. I regret that this has come to my knowledge.

Yours obedient servant,

Dear Sir,

I wish to inform you that I am not teaching here anymore although I was appointed to do so last spring. The Indian agent was very pleased with the way I was doing my work.

The Indians are ready to begin my work this year but I will not go to see them because I am not sure what they want me to do. They want me to teach them how to read and write. I have been doing this for many years and I believe I can help them.

I have been working hard to get my salary paid. I have been working for many years and I believe I deserve my salary. Teachers who are deprived of their schools are entitled to their years' salary.

I did my work well and the things that he accused me of
were just what someone who told me told him they are very personal and have no connection at all with my teaching.

I had and still have some debts to pay from. I don't know what resources I'm going to use for this month and indeed it only as pay me off for what I've been doing quite a bit of money here preparing to open my school.

She did the best she could even tell you last year about how I had to buy practically everything for the school. She couldn't get me anything. I had to supply even such articles as pencils. Hope this will make you understand why I have spent that cheque paying for bills and also why I think I have a right to my salary.

If he had told me last spring that I was not to teach here again
I might have gone to work and applied for some other school.

I got married last week and now I am free for all work. I am trained to be a teacher and have no idea of housework and cooking so could not very well go out and work in that line.

Dear Sir:

You are quite correct I did take this matter up with you and Mr. Phelan when I was in the Department on June 16th. You agreed that if the school could be built without cost to the Department, it would be in order to go ahead.

You will also recall that I told you that the old school is badly in need of repair, in fact, would need a new foundation and joice. Besides, there would not be one pupil to attend school there.

It is expected that the school will be completed for October 1st and Miss Kelly has been informed of the change and has agreed to continue as teacher of the Lake Penache school.

MEMORANDUM TO FILE:

WHITEFISH LAKE (R.O.) INDIAN DAY SCHOOL

I was only able to visit this school on a Sunday and therefore it was not in operation.

TEACHER

Mrs. Petahtagoose has a first class certificate and has had 5 years' experience. She seems a bright and capable enough teacher and is definitely interested in her pupils. She has a large family herself and at times seems more interested in her family than in the school. She has made her classroom attractive and is quite keen to learn of new methods and on the whole would seem to be satisfactory. She lives with her husband in a small house near the school.

BUILDING

This is a temporary structure which is gradually being converted into a permanent one. It has now been covered with insul brick and is beginning to look attractive. The inside is covered with Ten Test and is in need of a coat of paint in order to help brighten the inside. Mr. Marleau is planning small teacher's quarters and cloak-room for the back of the building. As the structure has no basement or furnace it departs greatly from our standard plan. However, it will serve the needs of these Indians, particularly in view of the fact that the mill has now closed down. Therefore there is a possibility that some of these Indians or all of them may move away.

Ottawa, December 5, 1932.

I have to inform you the Department is advised that Mrs. Irene Burnett, teacher of the Whitefish Lake Indian Day School, has given up duties, on account of ill health. It is doubtful if she will be able to return during the balance of the present school year.

With further reference to your letter of the first instant, to the effect that Miss Spottawood had given up duties as teacher of the Whitefish Lake Indian Day School, I now have to inform you that the Department is approving of the appointment of Miss Irene Denlen, Perth Bay, Ont., to begin duties on or about the 16th instant. Miss Denlen obtained a Second Class Professional Certificate at Perth Bay Normal last August but, so far, she has had no teaching experience. I would request that you visit this school at the very earliest opportunity and give Miss Denlen any assistance you can in her work. If she requires any school materials or supplies for the residence, you should have her prepare and forward a requisition. Any assistance you can give her as she takes up duties will be appreciated. I have the honor to enclose herewith an account of £3.45, favor Mr. O'Leary, for four stoves supplied to Shingobee Lake Indian School, and in the same connection by respectfully to state that I am obliged under, covering the account to me, under date 27th Oct.

The fireplace and oven plate of cooking stove were all burned out so that it was impossible to bake in it. You will be pleased to note that I have purchased your prices (with the Chief's permission) I know that I should have applied to the Department for them, but it would have taken a long time before receiving the answer and I could not do without the use of the oven for baking bread which you will know that it is impossible to buy bread any nearer than Sudbury. Trusting that with your authority the Department will not object to paying for same.

I have the honor to be,

The Deputy Chief
of Indian Affairs,

Indian Office, Manitouining, May 18 1899

Sir,

Referring to Official Letter dated 19th April with reference to the construction of closets for the White Fish Lake Band, and instructing me to have a suitable building constructed in accordance with the plan enclosed so soon as weather would permit.

I have the honor to report that when I was at White Fish Lake last week making the distribution of interest money to the band, I made enquiries as to the practicability of getting the work done and was informed that the only way that the material for the work could be got to the reserve would be from Sudbury to Kemptor Station, from where it would have to be brought in (sic) a distance of about three or four miles and which would cost so much more than is usual for the Department to pay for such a building, I thought it was advisable to report for further instructions in the matter.

The husband of the School teacher offered to do the work but could not give me any idea as to cost of completing the same.

I have the honor to be

The Secretary
